noun.description: A utensil resembling a spoon, with a long handle and a deep bowl, used for removing powdered, granulated, or semisolid substances (such as ice cream) from a container.
A piece of news published by a newspaper or broadcast by a television or radio station in advance of its rivals.

verb.description: Pick up and move (something) with a scoop.
examples: Philip began to scoop grain into his bag

verb.description: Publish a news story before (a rival reporter, newspaper, or radio or television station).

origin: Middle English (originally denoting a utensil for pouring liquids): from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German schōpe waterwheel bucket; from a West Germanic base meaning draw water; related to the verb shape.
